content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a very interesting problem, creative while still being somewhat challenging.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one; doable but not too easy, and creative.

Edit:

- Changed test 2 (Tidy twos) & its validator orientation so a solution like this:

gets
a = $<.map{x=_1.chomp
$.%2<1?x:x.reverse}.join
p a.split(?o).max.size+1

will fail earlier (you shouldn't be sorting lexicographically)

>======o
o===<o=<

became

>===o>=o
o======<

- Rewrote the solution slightly differently for validation.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
this looks cool, but id propably not make it within 15min :(
nice one - upvoted !
nice
This could be nice for a clash of code.

Goal section
* Suggest to change the second and third paragraphs as:

The box is perfectly filled with snakes from top to bottom in a zigzag manner, starting at the top left facing right.

The snakes have a generally horizontal* orientation, and switch direction at the left and right edges of the box. A snake may span across more than one line.

Each snake has a tail ({{<}} or {{>}} depending on the direction), a body (each segment is a {{=}}) and a head ({{o}}).

(* vertical zigzag is possible, hence "horizontal" is mentioned.)

Constraints section
* (I haven't checked but I assume that's the case?) Suggest to add that each snake has at least one body segment (i.e. at least length 3).

Stub generator
* The variable name "H" differs from that used in the other sections ("n").

Cases
* Perhaps the clash is doable in Reverse if there are easier cases at the beginning (e.g. first pair is just 1 snake, second pair is 1 snake in 1st line and 2 snakes in 2nd line, third pair is 1 snake spanning across 1.5 lines and 1 snake filling the remaining 0.5 line)?

Thanks.

P.S. There's also this puzzle: https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/no-more-pythons-please
But of course yours is easier.
Is this doable in reverse?

Since I did this clash recently: there's this https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/6297da4535f7d32b19e3065d7e3dda627df3
that is similar, in that it has snakes on the title and there's ascii involved... I think that's fair.

Oh I just approved, but reading this question I realized I forgot to check it with reverse in mind. Reverse might be challenging - counting characters is always a bit annoying and here it is in combination with also the left/right dynamic. You do have quite some small examples, but it might help if there is just one more very short one, like
2
>=o>==
o==<o=
(answer 5)

Actually your 'Example val'  is a short one, but the Example itself with '8' is already a bit on the long end for counting during reverse.

- Added your statement with some very minor punctuation changes.
- (Also speficied there and in the constraints section about the body of the snake being always of length at least 1)
- Changed H to n in the stub
- Added the suggested examples and the reverse mode. Now the statement example became test 4, so I added that to the statement too. It's a bit confusing but it should be ok.

Thanks!

Edit: Yeah I forgot about that puzzle. I guess it has snakes and some ascii. I'm a fraud...
Thanks for your feedback. Any suggestion on how to make it easier? What was the hardest part for you?
Please always write a reason when you approve or reject a contribution. Thanks.

Hardest part for me would probably be snakes going left to right, and then right to left. 
But I'm very new to programming, so it's just me. Would take a while longer, but definitely doable.
Great puzzle, hope to solve it one day in a clash.
Good luck!

Sorry I'm not sure I understand.

But anyway I don't mind adding a testpair. Did you mean to add it after the Example or before?

Or should I shorten (in width) everything that comes before (including) the Trimming test?

Sorry for the unclarity. What I mean is that for a reverse player, connecting the output to the input is challenging for any longest snake longer than 5 (i.e. counting characters is annoying in IDE). Your first two test/val pairs can be followed because the snakes are on a single line, but your first switching example's longest snake is rather long (11), and the one after that as well (8); I guess that for a reverse player it will be challenging to make the connection that it shifts from left to right while trying to count the '=' characters on his screen.

I cannot anymore clearly check how it is as reverse, because I already know the assignment. But, I think that it is challenging, and I think it gets easier if as third test/val pair you do a switching case with a short (e.g. 5) longest snake, like the one I suggested.

LOL I'm not sure whether I made it any clearer with this. I'm not sure how to say it, but it comes down to: add one or more cases in which the longest snake is still small and hence easily countable for a reverse player.
I made every test before trimming to be shorter while testing for the same bit of logic. If you think that's not enough, let me know and I will add more tests.
I think that is enough, thanks.
